text: today on Applied Science we're going to
talk about corrosion inhibitors these
are really clever molecules that you've
probably heard about before think of the
last time that you saw an advertisement
for engine oil this one even says
clinging molecules protect from the
start and has this ridiculous textured
sticker to let you know why you need
their molecules in your engine but what
is a corrosion inhibitor anyway this is
actually one case where the marketing
speak is almost exactly correct it's a
it literally forms a protective film on
metal parts and prevents the part from
rusting and the effects are really
dramatic so for example this is a part
that I coated with just plain oil and
this is a part that I coated with oil
and just 2% of this magic corrosion
inhibitor solution and after five hours
an assault spray you can see the results
are super dramatic the way that these
corrosion inhibitors functioned though
is usually a trade secret and so
everyone wants to have their own secret
recipe of how these things are work but
in today's video we're gonna uncover
some of these secrets we're going to
talk about how to synthesize the
chemical in the lab and then how to test
it in various different corrosive
environments let's talk about how iron
rusts in the first place the process
requires both water and oxygen and in
this diagram we're looking at a
cross-section of a piece of iron with a
water droplet on it and so this process
is also two steps so in step one some
electrons leave an iron atom which
causes it to be a charged ion and the
charged ion is slightly soluble in water
so it actually leaves the surface of the
metal and is now wandering around in
this droplet of water and at the same
time the electrons that it gave up
migrate over here they can because the
iron is conductive of course and then
the oxygen combines with a water
molecule in these electrons to form an
OHA
minus charge and then this combines with
the positive iron ion that's wandering
around in the water droplet and that
produces iron oxide so it's a redox
reaction because there's both reduction
and oxidation happening so why does salt
actually make this process go faster a
long time ago I thought this was because
the chlorine was interacting chemically
with this process which it might
slightly but the real factor is that the
salt molecules ionized in this water
droplet and
just increase the general electrical
conductivity so this whole process
relies on the fact that all these ions
can move around freely within this water
droplet so the iron ions have to move
over from here the O H ions have to move
over from here and in pure water even
perfect ph7 pure water is very slightly
conductive just because randomly some of
the h2o molecules become H and O H which
are charged in the nuts that provides a
slight amount of conductivity but if you
dump a whole bunch of salt into here
then that makes everything way more
conductive in the malt and these ions
can move much much much more easily
through the water and that's what causes
that salt to be so much more corrosive
so how do we stop this process from
happening
one really common technique is just to
paint the surface of the metal so if we
put a mechanical barrier of polymer in
here that's good because it just holds
away the oxygen and water just
mechanically unfortunately that's not
really going to work inside an engine
because we need these metal parts to be
exposed so another technique is to use a
sacrificial anode and this is basically
a piece of zinc that we attach
electrically to the iron and the way
this works is instead of the electrons
preferentially or instead of the
electrons heading over to here and
causing a problem they prefer to go into
the sacrificial anode because the anode
is more reactive and it provides
basically a lower resistance path for
those electrons so we break the cycle of
this redox by adding in this piece of
zinc but this really only works for
things that are in a conductive
environment like the ocean for example
so this is pretty common to use on ships
but it's not just again it's not really
gonna work in an engine because there's
nothing really there's no seawater
involved or anything so the last
technique and what we're going to talk
about in this video is a chemical layer
that goes on the surface that is not a
polymer it's it's part of the oil itself
or at least it's mixable with the oil
and still provide some blocking
basically it keeps the electrons from
interacting with the oxygen of the
surface here and prevents breaks the
cycle of this redox but is essentially
just one molecule thick and here's the
special molecule that's going to be
doing most of the work of this job to 5
dimer capped o 1 3 4 Thea daya's ol and
so we'll break this thing down a
just means a five position ring that has
two nitrogens in it and interestingly
easels are used to cure athlete's foot
they're actually anti-fungal agents that
are can be sprayed on the body but not
this particular one the numbers
basically just indicate the positions on
the ring of where all these things are
so the asel has two nitrogens and so we
want to specify where those are on the
ring so one two three four so the three
four indicates that the two nitrogens
are up here and the one indicates that
there's a sulfur here so thea is the
prefix for sulfur containing so it's
basically sulfur on one and nitrogen on
three and four so that basically
specifies this ring and it's basically
just assumed that the positions we don't
specify our carbon so it's five
positions nitrogen on positions three
and four sulfur on position one and
carbon on the rest and then we just add
on dimer cap toe at positions 2 and 5 so
dimer cap toe is this sulfur hydrogen
and we basically just tacked those on at
positions two and five this thing goes
by a lot of different names
it's called bismuth e all here but I can
think that's a trade name but I'm just
going to call it DMT D the reason that
this molecule is useful is because the
sulfur reacts with the metal surface so
if we put a whole bunch of these
molecules on top of an iron surface the
sulfur will preferentially stick itself
right to the surface and the rest of
this molecule will be sitting there on
the surface we almost have this layer of
protective molecules forming itself on
the surface of the iron but there are a
couple of problems one this is a solid
it's a white it's a yellow powder that
actually looks a lot like sulfur itself
or kind of powdered it smells and looks
like powdered egg yolks we can't really
put that in our engine oil because the
powder would just sink to the bottom and
it's not particularly effective so what
we'd like to do is graft on to this
molecule something that's oily because
then what we would have is the sulfur
sticking to the surface of the metal and
then if we have oil molecules hanging
off this thing that's basically like
sticky oil that would get right onto the
surface and help the oil the rest of the
oil basically hang on and so that's what
we're going to do in
the synthesis we're gonna take one DMT D
molecule and conveniently with these two
dimer capped off here what we're going
to do is add oleic acids to each side of
this so we're going to make this giant
molecule here and now we have basically
a sulfur which sticks to the metal
surface its metallo philic and then
we're gonna have oily molecules that are
sticking off the sides here so we
basically come up with this joiner
molecule that makes oil stick better to
metal because it's got metal loving
parts here and oil loving parts out here
so it's a pretty simple synthesis we all
we have to do is add oleic acid to DMT D
heated up and stir it and we'll end up
with this product it basically has no
side products it's literally just
crafting these two other molecules onto
the side but what's simple in concept is
usually not so simple in practice and so
we do have some considerations here the
biggest one is that this reaction has to
take place at about 200 degrees C and at
that temperature oleic acid will react
with the air and decompose before it has
a chance to create our desired product
here so I gave it a shot anyway just to
see what would happen and after only
about 30 minutes or so I could tell that
the solution was no longer liquid it
basically formed a solid wax and this is
definitely not what we want but it was
worth a shot anyway just to try it I
basically put the things in the test
tube and stuck the test tube in a hot
sand bath and I could see that wasn't
going to work so the next thing I tried
was to put a glass tube into the into
the test tube and then just use some
foil to kind of make a you know a crude
kind of seal around it like this and I
pumped argon into the glass tube at a
very low flow rate and just thought that
you know the argon would basically keep
the air out and that kind of worked but
again it really it didn't produce a good
product I didn't let the reaction run
long enough but even then I could tell
that something wasn't good happening and
so I abandoned that too and had to
invest in a little bit more glassware so
the setup that ended up working well for
me is to have a round bottom flask in a
hot sand bath and then we've got a
thermometer down in the sand as well
we can control the temperature of the
sand then there's a distillation like
elbow here and I'm using this
thermometer coupler with a glass tube in
it and - the glass tube I connect a hose
that goes to my argon supply and I've
got a needle valve over here that
controls the flow rate in and then to
make sure that oxygen doesn't get in
anywhere into the system I have this
tubing adapter with the tube coming off
going into water and the idea there is
that I can count the bubbles coming out
to see what the flow rate is and then
the water trap also serves to keep down
any noxious stuff that's coming out of
there or at least try to minimize it
since we're dealing with sulfur here
these reactions are definitely not going
to smell that great and it does in fact
smell like a pretty stinky sulfur but
when this thing is running but you know
anyway on the bright side there was a
very slight distillation product so
there could have been an impurity or
maybe there was a side reaction that I
didn't anticipate and there was a very
very light oily substance that condensed
in the glassware and the odor of this
was actually surprisingly Pleasant it
was some other hydrocarbon substance
that was almost minty and smell was
actually kind of interesting but anyway
the reaction proceeded pretty well with
this setup I purged the whole thing with
argon gas if you follow the tube all the
way back it goes to my welding cylinder
and after purging it with argon for a
while I heated it up and the reaction is
pretty slow it took about 20 hours in
total to make 10 or 20 ml of this stuff
and we weigh out the ingredients DMT D
and oleic acid based on the fact that we
want two molecules of oleic acid for
every one molecule of DMT D and if we
multiply out all the molecular weights
and everything we get this ratio the
product is this extremely viscous dark
red-brown liquid and it doesn't have
much of an odor to it it's actually sort
of a mildly pleasant odor very mild and
I had fun pouring it around because it's
just so incredibly viscous and even got
some high speed video of it forming a
drop in mid air in order to test this
out what I wanted to start with an oil
base that
definitely did not have any corrosion
inhibitors in it and so I chose vacuum
pump oil this black gold because I know
that it's very very pure oil and so I
used that as the base and then to test
out very small percentages of this
corrosion inhibitor based on DMT D I
added just a few drops it ends up being
just about 2% by weight of the corrosion
inhibitor to the base oil and then to
test it out I would paint these
substances on to little test pieces of
steel and then put the steel in
corrosive environments to see how well
the corrosion inhibitor performs so to
test this chemical out I initially had
three samples a bare piece of metal
metal with just plain oil on it and
metal with oil and the corrosion
inhibitor and I came up with this test
chamber to see which you know to see how
much better the corrosion inhibitor
would perform and I spent a lot of time
you know putting this together
it's got like a flat silicone heater in
the bottom there that's controlled by a
PID thing and I've got a thermocouple in
there to control the air temperature and
then I would put water in that petri
dish that's in the bottom so that the
heater would sort of vaporize some of
the water and I've got a fan for good
circulation in there and then I even had
like a double paned window for
insulation and I had to put a resistor
in here to keep condensation from
forming and I basically messed around
with this thing for days and days and
it's true I got some good results out of
it but it's actually poorly designed and
I'll show you why it's actually a key
thing what we want to do when we when we
want to corrode metal is have a drop of
water form on the surface of the metal
and then we want that drop to basically
go away or recede so that oxygen can get
in there and flood the site and then we
want water to form again and then oxygen
to form again remember we want basically
water and oxygen all at the surface all
at the same time so submerging steel
into water even saltwater doesn't
corrode it that fast because there's not
as much oxygen inside the water we
really need air and and water so the
idea here is that in one of these
condensing chambers we have water vapour
coming up condensing on the metal and
then dripping off so we have this
constant influx of water and a constant
exposure to air the problem with this
thing Stephen got a styrofoam top the
the problem with this is that it
it's such a good insulator the metal
eventually gets up to the dew point and
so it won't form more dew on there
because I mean it's basically condensate
they won't condensate very quickly
because the metal warms up and since
it's this great insulated box everything
in here becomes about 50 degrees C and
then you don't get as much of this
rainfall action anymore so even though
this system ended up not working out
very well for the high humidity test I
did get something interesting out of it
which is an accidental discovery I glued
these windows on with silicone RTV right
out of a tube and what this does is out
gas acetic acid that's actually how the
RTV cures and the acetic acid gas is
actually quite corrosive and so if you
look at the results you can see that the
corrosion inhibitor did in fact do its
job even if this was a when I
was using about 0.7% even at that low
concentration there was a very
noticeable effect where the bare metal
was attacked significantly worse than
the corrosion inhibited version so I
finally gave up on the styrofoam box in
order to avoid any more acetic acid
problems or temperature problems or
whatever and actually came up with a
simpler way of doing this it's just a
beaker on the hot plate and I put some
foil around here to retain as much
temperature as possible but it's just
water in the bottom and then get the
samples as cool as possible I put this
aluminum fin sticking out of the top and
use magnets to attach the steel samples
to this piece of aluminum so the idea
here is that the water vapor comes up
here and the cool aluminum wilcott will
you know cool the steel down and
condensate will form more it's much more
rapidly on there and this worked really
well actually and I could control the
air temperature just by controlling the
water temperature and how much foil was
on here so again we were shooting for an
air temperature about 50 degrees C at a
hundred percent condensing humidity and
then the only last problem with this is
that of course the beaker walls would
form tons of humidity too and for the
camera I can't see in there so I added
this hot air reflow wand blowing like
100 degrees C air out here it's sort of
a defroster just so we can see the stuff
more clearly and do a time-lapse so this
worked really well and I got some great
result
out of it as you can see just plain oil
allowed the steel to rust pretty badly
and the oil with 1.5 percent corrosion
inhibitor is perfect absolutely no spot
of corrosion on there whatsoever and a
couple interesting things to note the
color of the rust from the acetic acid
corrosion is different from the color of
the rest in just air and water and I
think this may be because it's forming
iron acetate up here or something I'm
not really sure but all of the other
rests that I formed with the salt water
and just the water and air as you'll see
later is this orange e color and the
acetic acid stuff has this distinct
brownish color anyway I also started

this is actually the the Magnatech
caster all you know magic molecules and

actually corroded a little bit it wasn't
as good as my own corrosion inhibitor
which made me happy and then also it
seemed like this is a synthetic oil
which I thought might be interesting to
test most of its sort of anti corrosion

became waxy when it was subjected to

it was literally just a mechanical thing
essentially just paint at that point but
I also tested deoxy which is this really
great contact cleaner in fact what
launched this entire investigation one
day I was looking at this on the shelf
thinking what's actually in dioxin that
makes it work and one of the components
is an anti-corrosion chemical very
likely like the one we synthesized today
the reason being that deoxys removes
surface oxide it is deoxidized rahl and
then after you've removed surface oxide
you want to replace it with something
that's not going to allow further
corrosion to happen
so there's definitely anti-corrosion
chemicals in there and as sure enough it

corrosion on the d oxide so I was really
encouraged by these results but it was
still taking forever it was like 20
hours even to get to a small amount of
corrosion so I went to an even more
aggressive corrosion test the salt fog
test not the velvet fog but the
lesser-known salt fog and a way to do
this is to
get one of these ultrasonic foggers and
put it into a tub of saltwater that I
mixed up until it tasted like seawater
and I hung the samples such that the
test face was facing away from the
fogger so the only way that the test
face of these steel parts could
experience the salt fog is for the fog
to waft around them and then touch the
surface there was no spraying involved
and it was actually not quite as
aggressive as I thought it still took
about 24 hours and the effects were
quite good but again I was looking for
sort of more contrast like I basically
wanted to corrode all the samples to
some extent so we could see what the

wd-40 deoxy plain oil this is that
Blackmagic vacuum pump oil oil with 1.5%

we're making and then a bear piece of
metal and I also found out something
else interesting the steel shim stock
that I'm using comes with some kind of
corrosion inhibited oil coating and I
found this out because initially I was
prepping the samples by just cleaning
them with trichloroethane or something
or something very aggressive that I
thought I was removing all of the oil
from the surface but after putting them
into a corrosive environment even the
bare metal pieces were not corroding as
fast as I thought they should so the
next step was to take a scotch brite pad
and prep the pieces with that to make
sure that there was bare metal exposed
no corrosion protected metal allowed to
start the test off and then I had much
more consistent results after doing that
so finally to end things out I went to
the most aggressive test possible the
salt spray test and so I used the same
ultrasonic fogger machine but this time
I positioned the samples facing the
fogger spray so that it was constantly
experiencing droplets of salt water
being flung at it and there's air going
into there so it's how oxygen and salt
water converging on the surface for a
lot further you know the whole test and
did these tests at slightly above room
temperature 30 degrees C and after just
five hours the bare metal is just
completely corroded away the Castrol
magnetic molecules didn't work
very well either the wd-40 didn't work
that well however the deoxy and the oil
with 2% of our special DMT debased
anti-corrosion and a corrosion inhibitor
worked really well again I love these
results because it's just so dramatic I
mean there's a few tiny spots of rust on
here but this thing is just completely
obliterated so I admit that the
corrosion inhibitor we made today is not

up in the oil long enough you know for
hours even to be painted onto a surface
and to be tested properly so in actual
products like engine oil they add yet
more chemicals called dispersants I
think that will help this corrosion
inhibitor stay suspended in the oil so
that it can come into contact with the
metal parts another interesting fact I
came across while researching this is
the performance additives that are put
in gear oil so if you've ever opened a
bottle of this you know it smells
terrible it smells like sulfur and the
reason is that these extreme pressure
additives are sulfur based but we know
that sulfur reacts with iron in fact it
corrodes it so they put more corrosion
inhibitors in this oil to prevent its
own extreme pressure additives from
corroding the parts that it's supposed
to protect it's kind of cool that you
can get away with adding both corrosive
stuff and anti corrosive stuff to the
oil and its overall performance goes up
in both ways kind of a cool relationship
the reason that I call this example two
